title.children: Israel says strikes on refugee camp killed senior Hamas leader, Palestinian officials say 50 people dead

image.altText: Israeli forces' flares light up the night sky in northern Gaza Strip

items.synopsis: Hamas's tunnels under Gaza are a prime target for Israel as it expands its ground offensive in the north of the enclave after three weeks of aerial bombardment.

title.children: Ground-level clashes intensify as Israeli military confirms deadly strikes on Gaza refugee camp

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Rafah border crossing will be opened on Wednesday for a number of Palestinians who were injured in Gaza to complete their treatment in Egyptian hospitals, Egyptian medical and security sources said. It comes shortly after the United States said it was "intensely focused" on getting the Rafah crossing opened for Americans and foreigners to leave Gaza. State Department spokesperson Matthew Miller added Washington had made good progress on this. "We are intensely focused on getting the gate open. "We have made good progress on this even in the past few hours and hope to keep making progress to get those American citizens out," Miller said. Reporting with Reuters
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Rafah crossing to be opened for injured Gazans to complete treatment in Egypt

children.content: The
Rafah border crossing
will be opened on Wednesday for a number of
Palestinians who were injured in Gaza
to complete their treatment in
Egyptian hospitals
, Egyptian medical and security sources said.
It comes shortly after the United States said it was "intensely focused" on getting the Rafah crossing opened for Americans and foreigners to leave Gaza.
State Department spokesperson Matthew Miller added Washington had made good progress on this.
"We are intensely focused on getting the gate open.
"We have made good progress on this even in the past few hours and hope to keep making progress to get those American citizens out," Miller said.
Reporting with Reuters

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Here in Jerusalem, you see Israeli Defense Force (IDF) soldiers everywhere. Israelis serve in the military once they turn 18, with men serving 32 months and women doing 24 months. After that, almost everyone remains in the reserves until they turn 40. Israel summoned roughly 360,000 reservists to join the fight against Hamas after the attack on October 7. Many of them were living overseas and they dropped everything to return home. The ABC met up with Australian-Israeli Yaacov Travitz in Jerusalem. He was in Australia when the attack happened, and immediately hopped on a plane. "I was not expecting to come back to fight. I hate fighting. I'm over it. I spent a lot of my life fighting, both in service as well as afterwards in private security. I thought I was done with it but I felt like I was needed and my talents could be put to good use to protect people. " Yaacov's daughter lives in Jerusalem with his ex-partner, and being here for her was also a big reason for him to come back. "My hope is that I can keep her safe for long enough until this is over. And then everything goes back to normal, she goes to school, her mum goes to work. And everything just goes back to normal, with people just trying to live without the hate, without the violence."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Australian-Israeli returns to Jerusalem to join IDF reserves and protect his daughter

children.content: Here in Jerusalem, you see Israeli Defense Force (IDF) soldiers everywhere. Israelis serve in the military once they turn 18, with men serving 32 months and women doing 24 months. After that, almost everyone remains in the reserves until they turn 40.
Israel summoned roughly 360,000 reservists to join the fight against Hamas after the attack on October 7. Many of them were living overseas and they dropped everything to return home.

props.alt: A man pushes a girl on a swing

children.content: Yaacov Travitz flew to Jerusalem after the October 7 attack.
(ABC News: Lauren Day)
The ABC met up with Australian-Israeli Yaacov Travitz in Jerusalem. He was in Australia when the attack happened, and immediately hopped on a plane.

"I was not expecting to come back to fight. I hate fighting. I'm over it. I spent a lot of my life fighting, both in service as well as afterwards in private security. I thought I was done with it but I felt like I was needed and my talents could be put to good use to protect people. "
Yaacov's daughter lives in Jerusalem with his ex-partner, and being here for her was also a big reason for him to come back.

"My hope is that I can keep her safe for long enough until this is over. And then everything goes back to normal, she goes to school, her mum goes to work. And everything just goes back to normal, with people just trying to live without the hate, without the violence."
Yaacov just wants his daughter, who lives in Jerusalem, to have a normal life.
(ABC News: Lauren Day )

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The city of Sderot is one of the closest places you can get to near the Gaza border and you can usually have a clear view into the northern parts of the enclave. I’ve been here watching the war inside Gaza. It means we’ve been able to see the evidence of Israeli’s constant bombardment into the north – building after building that is damaged or completely destroyed. The whole area looks like a big grey pile of ash, because any of the buildings that are left standing are covered in concrete dust. It’s actually pretty eerie to look at. Almost every few seconds, we hear the battle unfolding on the ground. War planes fly overhead and then we hear a huge explosion – we see a massive plume of smoke rise into the sky. Another airstrike. Suddenly there are several loud bangs close by. Israeli tanks stationed near the Gaza border are firing from the ground into the Strip. I see several bright flashes of light, as artillery is fired. I can hear machine guns as Hamas militants are locked in gun battle with Israeli troops on the ground. It sounds like it’s coming from the north but we can’t be sure because the Israeli military isn’t really telling us a lot of information of what’s happening on the ground.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Here's what the ABC's Middle East correspondent can see 1km from Gaza's border

children.content: The city of Sderot is one of the closest places you can get to near the Gaza border and you can usually have a clear view into the northern parts of the enclave.

I’ve been here watching the war inside Gaza. It means we’ve been able to see the evidence of Israeli’s constant bombardment into the north – building after building that is damaged or completely destroyed.
The whole area looks like a big grey pile of ash, because any of the buildings that are left standing are covered in concrete dust. It’s actually pretty eerie to look at.

props.alt: An explosion in a night sky

children.content: Sderot in southern Israel is as close as journalists can get to Gaza.
(Reuters: Violeta Santos Moura)
Almost every few seconds, we hear the battle unfolding on the ground.
War planes fly overhead and then we hear a huge explosion – we see a massive plume of smoke rise into the sky. Another airstrike.
Suddenly there are several loud bangs close by. Israeli tanks stationed near the Gaza border are firing from the ground into the Strip. I see several bright flashes of light, as artillery is fired.
I can hear machine guns as Hamas militants are locked in gun battle with Israeli troops on the ground.
It sounds like it’s coming from the north but we can’t be sure because the Israeli military isn’t really telling us a lot of information of what’s happening on the ground.

image.altText: Firefighters stand near blackened ground as flames move up a hill near a property.

items.synopsis: Firefighters were kept busy overnight with dozens of bushfire warnings across southern Queensland and northern New South Wales with more property losses confirmed. Follow live

title.children: Number of homes lost in Queensland surpasses 2019 Black Summer bushfire season with more property losses confirmed

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Southern Downs Mayor Vic Pennisi has just spoken to News Breakfast: "I can confirm that there's been four homes lost in Wallangarra. However, the danger at this point in time has passed. People are beginning to move back into their homes which is great. "The fires when through very, very quickly from when the evacuation was called to when the fire got there. In the hills, they just move at a great pace of knots, especially when they're fanned with the wind. "Of course, the loss of any property would be devastating for those residents who have been affected. "And you know, my heart goes out to those people who have lost their properties. You know that your home is your castle. You've got so many family memories in there. You know, kids and photos and all those sorts of things. So I can't begin to imagine what those people who have lost their homes are going through at the moment. "But, you know, we didn't lose any people and you know, that's our primary concern is to make sure that our people are as safe as possible. And our Fire and Emergency Services have done a wonderful job."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Four more houses confirmed lost in Wallangarra overnight

children.content: (ABC News)
Southern Downs Mayor Vic Pennisi has just spoken to News Breakfast:
"I can confirm that
there's been four homes lost in Wallangarra
. However, the danger at this point in time has passed. People are beginning to move back into their homes which is great.

"The fires when through very, very quickly from when the evacuation was called to when the fire got there. In the hills, they just move at a great pace of knots, especially when they're fanned with the wind.
"Of course, the loss of any property would be devastating for those residents who have been affected.

"And you know, my heart goes out to those people who have lost their properties. You know that your home is your castle. You've got so many family memories in there. You know, kids and photos and all those sorts of things. So I can't begin to imagine what those people who have lost their homes are going through at the moment.
"But, you know,
we didn't lose any people
and you know, that's our primary concern is to make sure that our people are as safe as possible. And our Fire and Emergency Services have done a wonderful job."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Reporting by Kirsten Webster and Danielle Mahe The Rural Fire Service believes an arsonist is active on the Gold Coast hinterland. Crews were called back to the Bonogin Valley at 6:40am on Wednesday, following reports a fire they believe was deliberately lit yesterday reignited. Six fires were lit along a road on Tuesday, prompting crews to respond rapidly to stop them spreading in the dry, hot conditions. Chief Superintendent Alan Gillespie said crews managed to get to the fires quickly. "We were able to scramble resources fairly quickly and they are all out but we will be quite vigilant" Mr Gillespie said. "It is just incredible that people are doing stupid things like that," he said A Queensland Fire and Emergency Services (QFES) spokesman said the reignited fire had been extinguished. Mr Gillespie says they have a number of leads, and that police are investigating. "I just can't understand the mentality of people who go out and put the community and our firefighters on the line and under risk just for some perverse thrill of seeing vehicles responding to fires." Queensland Police have been contacted for comment.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Authorities believe arsonist is active in Gold Coast hinterland

children.content: Reporting by Kirsten Webster and Danielle Mahe
The Rural Fire Service believes an arsonist is active on the Gold Coast hinterland.
Crews were called back to the Bonogin Valley at 6:40am
on Wednesday, following reports
a fire they believe was deliberately lit yesterday
reignited.
Six fires were lit along a road on Tuesday, prompting crews to respond rapidly to stop them spreading in the dry, hot conditions.
Chief Superintendent Alan Gillespie said crews managed to get to the fires quickly.
"We were able to scramble resources fairly quickly and they are all out but we will be quite vigilant" Mr Gillespie said.
"It is just incredible that people are doing stupid things like that," he said
A Queensland Fire and Emergency Services (QFES) spokesman said the reignited fire had been extinguished.
Mr Gillespie says they have a number of leads, and that police are investigating.

"I just can't understand the mentality of people who go out and put the community and our firefighters on the line and under risk just for some perverse thrill of seeing vehicles responding to fires."
Queensland Police have been contacted for comment.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The loss of homes around Tara, on Queensland's Western Downs, has now surpassed the total number of homes lost in Queensland during the 2019 Black Summer fire season. As firefighters have battled blazes in that region for nearly two weeks, with four houses confirmed destroyed in Wallangarra overnight, and 53 destroyed around Tara, for a total of 57, compared to 49 across the state in 2019. Paul McVeigh, mayor of Western Downs Regional Council, said the loss had had a huge impact on the community. "The resilience of our community is very strong … but to be hit with so much devastation is a real challenge," he said. "Obviously housing will be our greatest need."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: More homes lost in Qld than in 2019 Black Summer

children.content: The loss of homes has had a huge impact on Tara.
(ABC News: Chris Gillette)
The loss of homes around Tara, on Queensland's Western Downs, has now surpassed the total number of homes lost in Queensland during the 2019 Black Summer fire season.

As firefighters have battled blazes in that region for nearly two weeks, with four houses confirmed destroyed in Wallangarra overnight, and 53 destroyed around Tara, for a total of 57, compared to 49 across the state in 2019.
Paul McVeigh, mayor of Western Downs Regional Council,
said the loss had had a huge impact on the community.
"The resilience of our community is very strong … but to be hit with so much devastation is a real challenge," he said.
"Obviously housing will be our greatest need."
